start.title: First day at the job
start.text: A programmer is hired for a new job at a tech company. He was told it would be a 'fun' position in a fast paced environment, where he would face 'interesting' problems and work with industry professionals. Upon arriving at the office, he finds most desks are empty. Asking around for his manager, he finds that most of the employees working there are also new hires, and arent familiar with who hes looking for. After wandering around the eerily empty office, you finally locate your new manager. He hands you a 2007 Lenovo ThinkPad, with a few keys missing. He starts to tell you about their app and codebase.

app_age.title: App's age revealed
app_age.text: The manager pauses, squinting as he calculates, 'Our app? Oh, it's about 17 years old. We've kept the original framework, and it runs on Python 2.3.'

choices.text: Flee from the building in horror

tech_stack.title: Tech stack horrors
tech_stack.text: He beams with pride, 'We've got a robust stack! It's mostly Flash and Java Applets. Oh, and we've just started to integrate Silverlight.'

choices.text: Light the laptop on fire for a ritualistic cleansing

lead_dev.title: Absent lead dev
lead_dev.text: He scratches his head, 'Lead dev? Well, we had one a while ago, but he's on a long vacation. We get a postcard from him every few months. Last one was from... Bali?'

database.title: Excel as a database
database.text: He shows you an Excel file named 'FINAL_REAL_DB_v32'. 'This is our database! We have a neat Visual Basic script writing to and reading from it.'

choices.text: Rush to the nearest window for fresh air

version_control.title: Version control via email
version_control.text: He chuckles, 'Oh, we just email the files to each other. If something goes wrong, there's always the recycle bin.'

choices.text: Set up a sacrificial altar for the ThinkPad

workflow.title: Reboot fixes everything
workflow.text: He says, 'It's simple. When something breaks, we fix it. Usually by turning it off and on again. Sometimes by hitting the server.'

choices.text: Hitting the server? Like an old TV? Thats not how tech works...

smack_the_server.title: Hitting the server? Like an old TV? Thats not how tech works...
smack_the_server.text: Did he say that they hit the server? This is not a good sign. You decide the best course of action is to just leave. On your way out you notice the server he was talking about. Looks like a 2013 macbook pro. You decide to hit it. It works. You leave the office, never to return.

code_review.title: What's a code review?
code_review.text: He raises an eyebrow, 'Code what now? We trust each other here. No need for those fancy processes.'

choices.text: 'Oh is that my phone I hear? gotta get that...'

pretend_to_get_call.title: Pretend to get a call
pretend_to_get_call.text: You pretend to get a call, and excuse yourself. You never return to the office.

backups.title: USB stick backups
backups.text: He confidently states, 'Every Friday, I copy the Excel file to my USB stick. Got dozens of them in my drawer.'

deployment.title: Live deployments
deployment.text: He grins, 'When we think something is ready, we just copy it over to the live server. We just send an email to users to tell them to stop using the app for a few minutes.'

security.title: Double-locked server room
security.text: He winks, 'Security is our top concern. That's why the server room door has two locks. And we never click on emails from princes.'

downtime.title: Server unplugs
downtime.text: He shrugs, 'Only when there's a power cut. Or when the cleaner unplugs the server to vacuum. Or when our popcorn machine blows a fuse, but movie night is only once a week.'

choices.text: Recommend a cloud solution, while heading for the door

horror_ending.title: Swift exit
horror_ending.text: You didn't even look back as you fled from the building, vowing to read job descriptions more carefully in the future.

missing_requirements.title: Missing requirements
missing_requirements.text: Python 2.3? You aren't sure if Pycharm would even support that. In a moment of clairvoyance, you realize that this is the first of many red flags. You pretend you're in the wrong office building, you were applying for a job at the company next door. You leave, never to return.

fire_ending.title: Burning first impression
fire_ending.text: You set the laptop on fire in a ritualistic attempt to cleanse the building of its technological sins. The fire alarm blares. Everyone evacuates. At least you made an impression on your first day!

laugh_ending.title: Uncontrollable laughter
laugh_ending.text: You burst into uncontrollable laughter, drawing the attention of the few remaining employees. You laugh all the way out of the building, realizing this was too absurd to be true.

leadership_opportunity.title: Leadership Opportunity
leadership_opportunity.text: That sounds... incredibly sketchy. Leadership is important, but maybe this is an opportunity.

choices.text: Maybe you could replace this guy and get a bigger paycheque. Ask about the deployment details to demonstrate your expertise.
The only dev disappeared? So all his work would fall on you too? Whats the salary again? Maybe this isnt such a good idea...

window_ending.title: Breath of fresh air
window_ending.text: You rush to the nearest window, fling it open and take several deep breaths. The crisp, fresh air clears your head. If you aim it just right, you might be able to land in those bushes and make an escape.

subtle_ending.title: Stealthy exit
subtle_ending.text: You subtly gather your belongings and head for the door. Your manager, deep in thought, doesn't even notice.

sick_ending.title: Feigned illness
sick_ending.text: You feign a sudden illness, clutching your stomach for added effect. 'I think I ate something bad,' you mutter, making a swift exit.

polite_ending.title: Graceful goodbye
polite_ending.text: You stand up, politely thank the manager for his time, and inform him you've made a grave mistake. You then stroll out with as much dignity as you can muster.

cloud_ending.title: Cloudy daydreaming
cloud_ending.text: You mention something about migrating to the cloud, but your voice trails off as you're already halfway to the exit. The skies outside seem to promise a brighter future.
